title: Local Wine Tasting in Martinborough: Hidden Gems
excerpt: Exploring the lesser-known wineries of Martinborough and discovering unique flavor profiles that showcase the region's terroir.
content: My sister and I sampling wine flights at a small family-owned vineyard in Martinborough

font-playfair text-2xl font-semibold my-4">The Big Names vs. The Little Guys

Everyone who visits wants to hit Ata Rangi and Palliser (can't blame them, both make incredible wines), but I've started playing tour guide by taking friends to the tiny places down gravel roads that don't make it into the guidebooks. Found this gem called Thompson's last week - literally just a weathered shed with a hand-painted sign. The "tasting room" was the winemaker's kitchen table, and his ancient Labrador slept at our feet while we tasted.

The guy (Tom, unsurprisingly) only makes about 200 cases of Pinot a year from his 2-hectare plot. No fancy machines – he was proudly showing us his antique grape press that's older than I am. His wines aren't polished or perfect, but there's something so honest about them. Picked up two bottles that were embarrassingly underpriced at $35 each. Felt like I was getting away with robbery.

He did this cool thing where he opened vintages from the last five years so we could taste how they'd developed. The differences were wild – 2021 was all bright fruit, while 2018 had this mushroomy, earthy thing happening. "That was the year it rained for all of March," he said, like the weather was obviously something I should be able to taste. Maybe someday.

Not Just Pinot (Though Mostly Pinot)

Look, I love Pinot as much as the next basic wine girl, but after your 17th Pinot tasting, you start craving ANYTHING different. Thankfully, a few brave souls are growing other stuff around here. Had an Albariño yesterday at Te Hera that blew my mind – all citrusy and minerally but with this rich texture that made me immediately crave seafood. The winemaker said they only started making it because his wife got sick of drinking Pinot every night. Relatable.

Another place is doing Tempranillo and Syrah in these tiny experimental batches. The Syrah was a bit meh (sorry!), but the Tempranillo was surprisingly delicious. Apparently, they only made like 50 cases, so I bought three bottles in a weird panic move, afraid I'd never see it again. My wine fridge (okay fine, it's just a regular fridge I'm not using for food) is getting worryingly full.

Finding My New Favorite

I've been on a mission to find my perfect Martinborough Pinot, and I think I finally discovered it yesterday – Luna Estate's Silver River Pinot Noir. It's not cheap, but it's an incredible treat that I'll be saving for special occasions. It has this amazing buttery texture and complexity that makes me understand why people get so passionate about Pinots from this region specifically. The winemaker laughed when I described it as "buttery" (apparently that's more of a Chardonnay descriptor), but he seemed pleased with my enthusiasm anyway.

What I love about Luna Estate is how unpretentious they are despite making such sophisticated wines. The tasting room is comfortable rather than fancy, and they took their time explaining each wine without making me feel stupid for asking basic questions. They've also got these amazing cheese platters that pair perfectly with their wine flight. I've already booked a return visit for when my parents come to visit next month.

Playing Tourist in My New Home

After years in hospitality, it's weird being on the other side. I can't stop analyzing tasting room experiences. Best one so far was at Cambridge Road where they did this blind tasting comparing their Pinot with ones from Central Otago, Marlborough, and even one from Burgundy (fancy!). I got exactly ONE right and it was the Central Otago because it practically punched me in the face with fruit (subtle, it was not).

Most surreal moment: when a tour group came through while I was at Poppies, and I realized the guide was giving them almost word-for-word the spiel I used to give hotel guests. Had to resist the urge to correct her when she mispronounced "Martinborough" with an American accent (it's Mar-tin-burra, not Martin-borough!).

Life Among the Vines

The farmers' market on Saturdays has become my religion. There's this elderly couple who sell the most incredible sourdough bread made with local wine yeast. Pairs perfectly with literally any wine, which is convenient because wine is basically a food group here. My grocery bill has gone down dramatically, but my wine expenditure... let's not talk about that.

My "cellar" (the cabinet under the stairs) is getting ridiculous. Started with the noble intention of aging special bottles, but who am I kidding? I have zero patience. Though I did manage to save a 2019 Dry River Pinot for my birthday next month – the winemaker swore it needed at least 5 years to show its best. We'll see if it survives that long.

For anyone planning to visit (yes, that's an invitation, Sydney friends!), skip the wine tour packages. They rush you through 5-6 places in a day which is A) too many and B) mostly the commercial spots. Rent bikes instead, pick 2-3 places max, and leave time to actually talk to the people making the wine. And for god's sake, eat before you start. Learned that lesson the hard way when I almost face-planted into a vineyard after trying to do a full day of tastings on just a muffin.

Never thought I'd end up in a place where the population is roughly equal parts humans and grapevines, but somehow it fits. Although I will say the dating pool is... limited. But that's a story for another day, preferably after several glasses of that Pinot I'm supposedly aging.
